Wisdom Of The Ages
Earlier this year, the Administration announced that senior professors
were going to be forced to retire at age
65. At that time, they also stated that the
new vacancies would be filled by new
Ph.D.'s who possessed "bright, young
energy." Of course, the Administration is
really more interested in the "bright,
small salaries" that the younger professors
will be getting, but that is par for the
course.
It is disturbing to see this nation's
narcissistic fixation with youth spreading
into academia. The college campus is the
one place where it should be obvious that
age and wisdom are often synonimous
and not, as the high-gloss media culture
would have us believe, mutually exclusive.
The federal law which pushes back

Wisdom Of The Ages
Earlier this year, the Administration announced that senior professors
were going to be forced to retire at age
65. At that time, they also stated that the
new vacancies would be filled by new
Ph.D.'s who possessed "bright, young
energy." Of course, the Administration is
really more interested in the "bright,
small salaries" that the younger professors
will be getting, but that is par for the
course.
It is disturbing to see this nation's
narcissistic fixation with youth spreading
into academia. The college campus is the
one place where it should be obvious that
age and wisdom are often synonimous
and not, as the high-gloss media culture
would have us believe, mutually exclusive.
The federal law which pushes back
mandatory reitrement to age 70 is an
ovetdue admission that America's mentality with regard to its older citizens is
not only morally indefensable, but
contrary to simple common sense as well.
It is to be deeply regretted that such a
fine remedial step contains a discriminatory loophole for exempting tenured
professors and only tenured professors
from enjoying the law's protection. In

what other occupation is forced retirement less justified?
The students have been reassured
that the vacated positions will be filled by
up and coming young bucks, but is this
really the case? Dean Suskind refuses to
talk about the promised replacements,
saying that it is wrong to discuss "personalities". (He must have learned that one
from Karl Block.) Also, since the beginning of the semester students have been
quietly learning that some young, associate professors will not be returning either.
The usual reason given for their departure
is that they haven't published the required
amount of scholarly articles. When the
vast amount of advising and paperwork
which the junior faculty are required to
do is considered, however, then a paucity
of scholarship becomes nothing more than
a convenient excuse.
What this all seems to boil down to
is that the faculty is going to be cut.
What is doubly aggravating is that the
Administration feels obligated to go about
it in such a cloak-and-dagger manner.
Why can't they level with the students
about unpleasant realities?
Perhaps
they've just forgotten how.
